titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the South Texas Jewish Archives vertical file, 1912-2023 MS 772

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Forms part of the South Texas Jewish Archives.
Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-02-07 14:18:18 -0600.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: South Texas Jewish Archives vertical file
did.abstract: The collection includes individual files within the South Texas Jewish Archives including materials including: newsclippings, notes, correspondence, photographs, and other materials. The contents are donated by community members and/or gathered by the HJHA staff.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Founded in 2017 in the wake of Hurricane Harvey, as the Houston Jewish History Archive, the name was changed in January 2023 to the Joan and Standford Alexander South Texas Jewish Archives (STJA). STJA is dedicated to the study and preservation of Jewish life in South Texas. By collecting artifacts from all facets of Jewish life, the STJA sheds light on how Jews in and around Houston have balanced maintaining their traditions and heritage with adapting to life in Texas and the United States.
For more information related to HJHA visit their website: https://jewishstudies.rice.edu/houston-jewish-history-archive

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes individual files from the South Texas Jewish Archives including: newsclippings, notes, correspondence, photographs, and other materials. The contents are donated by community members and/or gathered by the HJHA staff.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this collection have been arranged alphabetically in one series as follows:
Series I: STJA People, Places, and Events

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research. Stored onsite at the Woodson Research Center.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the South Texas Jewish Archives vertical files must be obtained from the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

The Woodson Research Center use policy is that researchers assume sole responsibility for any infringement of privacy, literary rights, copyrights, or other rights arising from their use of the archival materials. In addition to any restrictions placed by donors, certain kinds of archival materials are restricted for the life of the creator plus 50 years. These materials include, but are not limited to, student grades, transcripts, and any job applications or recommendations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by a variety of individuals and organizations starting in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: South Texas Jewish Archives vertical files, 1912-2022, MS 772, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

controlaccess.head: Subjects (Corporations)
controlaccess.corpname: United Orthodox Synagogues of Houston (Houston, Tex.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One typed draft of the book, "I Remember When," which is an anthology of essays written by residents of Seven Acres senior center as part of an essay writing contest. The volume was compiled by Emily Spector who was the chairperson of the Essay Committee.

did.unittitle: Event materials from "In Celebration of the Unveiling of 'Spring'" by Chaim Goldberg

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Chaim Goldberg was born in Kazimierz, Poland in 1917. He began to sculpt at the age of five and to paint when he was six. He was discovered at the age of 14 and taken under the patronship of several wealthy sponsors. He was admitted to the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw at the age of 17. He had a studio in Houston for a time where he created large format sculpture, paintings, and graphics in various media. He died in Florida in 2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The photo was taken at the construction site for Craig's Department store in Rice Village located at 2501 Univerisity Blvd. Persons in the photo from L to R are: Robert Grossman, Charles Grossman, Nancy Frimer Landa, and Gary Grossman (all children of the owners of Craig's).
